newsitem.title: SPAIN: New measures to fund Spain health spending - press.
newsitem.headline: New measures to fund Spain health spending - press.

text.p: Spanish Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato has reached an agreement with Catalan deputy Joaquin Molins to fund regional health spending of around 200 billion pesetas annually in the next five years, financial daily Cinco Dias reported on Wednesday.

The agreement between the government and its regional ally involves a tax hike on alcohol and tobacco, a rise in prescription charges according to income, and the removal of tax rebates for health spending. Furthermore, the management of medical checks in cases of temporary incapacity would be passed to private insurance firms, the unsourced report said.
No-one at the Economy Ministry or at the Catalan regional government was immediately available to comment.

Tax hikes on alcohol and tobacco may be effective from January, with the government receiving an extra 40 billion pesetas, while higher prescription charges would save 60 billion pesetas, Cinco Dias reported.
The removal of the health rebate would bring in 74 billion pesetas, while a change in the management of medical checks for temporary incapacity would save 35 billion pesetas.
